Author: Socrates
Plato
Content: The Euthyphro Dilemma is a problem raised by Socrates in Plato’s dialogue Euthyphro, challenging the foundation of morality in relation to divine authority. The dilemma asks: Is something good because the gods command it, or do the gods command it because it is good? If something is good simply because the gods command it, then morality becomes arbitrary. In theory, the gods could declare murder or cruelty as morally good, and we would have no standard to challenge them. This suggests morality is not based on any inherent truth, but merely on divine preference—which could change at any time. On the other hand, if the gods command something because it is already good, then morality exists independently of divine authority. This would mean even the gods are bound by moral truths that exist beyond them. However, this raises another issue: if morality is independent of divine will, then we do not need gods to understand right and wrong—moral truths could be discovered through human reason alone. The Euthyphro Dilemma remains a central issue in the philosophy of religion and ethics. It challenges the idea that morality comes solely from divine command and pushes the discussion toward reasoning beyond mere obedience to authority. Some religious philosophers attempt to resolve it by arguing that God’s very nature is inherently good, meaning His commands are neither arbitrary nor external to morality. Still, for many, the dilemma remains an open question that forces deeper reflection on the origins of moral truth.
